http://sws.geonames.org/1814991/ Meiling Xiao received her PhD degree in physical chemistry from the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2017. She worked at the University of Waterloo as a postdoc and joined Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry in 2021 as a full professor. She was selected for the Special Talent Program B of CAS and the Outstanding Youth Foundation of Jilin Province. She has published over 40 papers in J. Am. Chem. Soc., Angew. Chem. Int. Ed., Adv. Mater., etc. with over 5100 citations, H-factor 33. Her research interests include single-atom heterogeneous catalysis, fuel cells, and water electrolyzers. This work was supported by the National Key R&D Program of China (2022YFB4002000) , the National Natural Science Foundation of China (22232004) , the Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE) has garnered significant attention as a pivotal technology for converting surplus electricity into hydrogen for long-term storage, as well as for providing high-purity hydrogen for aerospace and high-end manufacturing applications. With the ongoing commercialization of PEMWE, advancing iridium-based oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts remains imperative to reconcile stringent requirements for high activity, extended longevity, and minimized noble metal loading. The review provides a systematic analysis of the integrated design of iridium-based catalysts in PEMWE, starting from the fundamentals of OER, including the operation environment of OER catalysts, catalytic performance evaluation within PEMWE, as well as catalytic and dissolution mechanisms. Subsequently, the catalyst classification and preparation/characterization techniques are summarized with the focus on the dynamic structure-property relationship. Guided by these understandings, an overview of the design strategies for performance enhancement is presented. Specifically, we construct a mathematical framework for cost-performance optimization to offer quantitative guidance for catalyst design. Finally, future perspectives are proposed, aiming to establish a theoretical framework for rational catalyst design. Graphical Abstract This review explores the integrated design of iridium-based OER catalysts for PEMWE, covering fundamentals, classification, preparation and characterization, and design strategies. Keywords Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis Oxygen evolution reaction Iridium-based catalyst Integrated design Cost-performance optimization 1 Introduction Energy, materials, and information are the three key pillars driving the advancement of human society [1]. Energy can be classified into traditional energy and new energy based on its formation process and technological maturity [2–4]. Traditional energy includes oil, coal, natural gas, and hydropower, while new energy encompasses wind energy, solar energy, nuclear energy, biomass energy, and hydrogen energy [5–7]. Hydrogen energy, as an important secondary energy source, is well-suited for long-distance transportation. It is primarily produced through methods such as fossil fuel reforming (gray hydrogen) and water electrolysis (green hydrogen) [8–10]. Although hydrogen production through fossil fuel reforming (mainly natural gas) currently dominates the market, the non-renewability of fossil fuels and the large amounts of greenhouse gases produced during the process highlight the necessity of developing renewable and environmentally friendly hydrogen production alternatives [11]. Water electrolysis for hydrogen production only requires electricity and water as raw materials. When the input electricity comes from green renewable energy sources like wind and solar power, and the water used is derived from hydrogen combustion, water electrolysis can achieve true energy renewability and zero pollution throughout the process [12]. Given the gradual depletion of fossil fuels and escalating environmental policy support globally, water electrolysis is anticipated to emerge as the mainstream hydrogen production method [13–15]. Hydrogen production via water electrolysis is classified into four types according to the electrolyte: Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE), alkaline water electrolysis, anion exchange membrane water electrolysis, and solid oxide electrolysis [16]. Compared to the other three technologies, PEMWE advantages stem from the mature proton exchange membrane preparation technology and the faster proton (H+) migration rate relative to hydroxide (OH–) and oxide (O2–) ions at identical temperatures. As a result, PEMWE not only achieves lower driving voltage and longer lifespan at high current densities (≥ 1 A cm–2) in environments below the boiling point of water but also has advantages such as compact device design, extremely high hydrogen purity (≥ 99.99%), and rapid dynamic response [17–19]. Thanks to these unique advantages of PEMWE, it is better suited for the local consumption of fluctuating renewable energy sources. Moreover, its ability to instantly produce ultra-high-purity hydrogen makes it nearly irreplaceable in specific application scenarios such as fuel cells, high-end electronics manufacturing, and aerospace industries [20,21]. To minimize the driving power in PEMWE, the anode oxygen evolution catalyst in PEMWE electrolyzers is pivotal. Currently, iridium-based catalysts dominate in commercial PEMWE electrolyzers due to the stability of iridium oxide, as well as the high activity and conductivity of iridium. Data from the U.S. DOE Hydrogen and Fuel Cell Technologies Office Multi-Year Program Plan (2024) show that the membrane component with catalyst-coated membrane constitutes 15% of PEMWE total costs (Fig. 1(a) ). Compared to the cathode and anode catalyst layers, the cathode catalyst layer based on commercial Pt/C catalysts can use as little as 0.2–0.4 mgPt cm–2, while the anode catalyst layer based on commercial iridium oxide catalysts can use as much as 2–4 mgIr cm–2, resulting in a nearly 10-fold difference in the usage of precious metals [22–27]. According to the data accessed from the Umicore Precious Metals Management on June 2, 2025 (Fig. 1(b)), the price of iridium (147.12 USD g–1) is 4.08 times that of platinum (36.02 USD g–1). Therefore, the iridium metal cost for a commercial iridium oxide coating per square centimeter is approximately 40.8 times the platinum metal cost for a commercial Pt/C coating. Unfortunately, reducing the use of iridium means a decrease in the number of active sites and a higher reaction frequency that each active site must withstand. Therefore, oxygen evolution catalysts must possess stronger activity and stability to meet the demand for reduced iridium usage. Designing such low-cost, high-activity, and durable iridium-based catalysts demands a fundamental understanding of systematic design principles for these materials. To address this need, our review comprehensively covers essential aspects, including fundamentals, classification, preparation and characterization, as well as design strategies. We aim to provide valuable guidance for researchers actively engaged in designing low-cost and high-performance iridium-based catalysts. 2 OER fundamentals 2.1 Operation environment of OER catalysts we will conduct a fundamental analysis of the voltage required to drive the acidic water electrolysis reaction. Based on this analysis, an in-depth exploration of the differences in operating environments between the three-electrode testing system and PEMWE electrolyzer will be carried out, thereby highlighting the significance of analyzing the specific operating environment of PEMWE electrolyzers. Subsequently, the specific operating environment of iridium-based OER catalysts within PEMWE electrolyzers will be investigated. The profound comprehension of the operation environment can significantly aid in the design of iridium-based catalysts tailored for PEMWE. The acidic water electrolysis reaction involves an endothermic reaction where liquid water (H2O(l)) dissociates into gaseous hydrogen (H2(g)) and oxygen (O2(g)) under applied electrical potential, as described by the overall reaction equation (Eq. (1)). This electrochemical transformation comprises two half-reactions, with the OER occurring at the anode (Eq. (2)) and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode (Eq. (3)). Based on the standard Gibbs free energy of formation (ΔG 0 = 2×237100 J mol–1) for 2 mol of liquid water under standard conditions (25 °C, 1 atm), the number of electron transfers (n = 4), and the Faraday constant (F = 96485 C mol–1), the theoretical decomposition voltage for water electrolysis can be calculated using Eq. (4) to be 1.23 V [28,29]. However, in practical water electrolysis, additional voltage is required to overcome various overpotentials: the cathode overpotential (η c) due to the free energy barrier of the cathode reaction, the anode overpotential (η a) caused by the free energy barrier of the anode reaction, the ohmic overpotential (η ohm) from the internal resistance of the circuit, and the diffusion overpotential (η diff) arising from the transport and diffusion of species. Thus, the actual applied voltage in water electrolysis is the theoretical voltage plus the sum of all overpotentials, as shown in Equation 5 [30–32]. The use of Pt/C cathode catalysts generally significantly reduces η c. Although iridium-based catalysts at the anode can lower η a, due to the complexity of the anode reaction and sluggish kinetics, η a remains significantly higher than η c [33]. This highlights the urgent need for the development of anode catalysts compared to cathode catalysts. (1) 2H2O → 2H2 + O2 (2) 2H2O → 4H+ + O2 + 4e– (3) 4H+ + 4e– → 2H2 (4) E theoretical ( 25 ° C , 1 atm ) = Δ G ° n F = 2 × 237100 J / mol 4 × 96485 C / mol ≈ 1.23 V (5) E actual (25 °C, 1 atm) = 1.23 V +η c + η a + η ohm + η diff The contributions of η ohm and η diff to the overall performance differ significantly between the three-electrode performance evaluation system and the PEMWE electrolyzers performance evaluation system. As shown in Fig. 2(a) , the three-electrode test system is presented, whereas Fig. 2(b) depicts the PEMWE electrolyzers setup. The three-electrode test system is widely used for pre-screening PEMWE anode oxygen evolution catalysts because it is easy to set up and reduces variable interference. As shown in Fig. 2(a), the acidic liquid electrolyte, which is rich in hydrogen ions (typically 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4 is used to simulate the localized pH ≈ 0 environment caused by proton exchange), can quickly supply protons and water to the catalyst [34]. As a result, η diff is typically not considered in the three-electrode test system. The three-electrode setup allows for iR compensation to subtract η ohm, where the external voltmeter measures the half-potential between the anode working electrode (WE) and reference electrode (RE), and the external ammeter measures the total current between the WE and counter electrode (CE). The final applied voltage after iR compensation and conversion to the reference potential is considered as η a, which is the anode overpotential. However, in the PEMWE electrolyzers shown in Fig. 2(b), the performance evaluation of oxygen evolution catalysts is generally based on the total driving voltage (E actual) of the entire cell, rather than just η a. The PEMWE electrolyzer consists of a proton exchange membrane (typically made from perfluorosulfonic acid resin, which acts as a solid electrolyte to conduct protons), closely integrated anode and cathode catalyst layers, anode porous transport layer (usually platinum-coated titanium felt to reduce η ohm), cathode porous transport layer (commonly made of hydrophobic carbon paper to prevent water flooding and uncoated titanium felt for higher mechanical strength), bipolar plates (which have flow channels on both sides in the stack, called bipolar plates, as opposed to single flow channel plates in a single electrolyzer), and end plates (which serve for insulation and fixation) [35]. Operating at high current densities, PEMWE electrolyzers exhibit amplified η ohm and η diff contributions to E actual, imposing stricter requirements on component performance [19,36,37]. Besides the different performance evaluation metrics, the anode in the PEMWE electrolyzers often faces higher oxidation potentials. A higher oxidation potential can cause conductive carbon materials to convert to CO2 and metal-based materials to oxidize [38]. Given the localized high-acid environment provided by the proton exchange membrane, the stable form in the anode catalyst layer will ultimately be the insoluble oxide. To rationally design iridium-based catalysts, it is crucial to understand their operational environment in PEMWE electrolyzers, and this environment is illustrated in Fig. 3 . Specifically, the iridium-based catalyst particles in the PEMWE electrolyzers form proton conduction channels in contact with Nafion binders or the proton exchange membrane. Additionally, the catalyst particles establish electronic conduction pathways through contact with the anode titanium mesh, which also provides voids that facilitate the diffusion of oxygen and water. The performance of the electrolyzers, as determined by the iridium-based catalyst, is influenced by two main factors: (a) Catalyst-related factors: intrinsic activity, structural stability, inherent conductivity, and the exposure of active sites. (b) Non-catalyst-related factors: bubble interference, contact resistance, water supply, and proton transport. The former requires research on strategies to enhance the activity and stability of iridium-based catalysts, while the latter necessitates an understanding of the factors influencing catalyst performance evaluation in the electrolyzers. 2.2 Catalytic performance evaluation in PEMWE electrolyzers Accurately understanding the factors that influence the performance expression of oxygen evolution catalysts in PEMWE electrolyzers is a crucial prerequisite for rationally utilizing the performance of PEMWE electrolyzers to evaluate catalyst performance. The amount of catalyst used for oxygen evolution can lead to variations in the thickness of the anode catalyst layer, subsequently affecting both the ohmic resistance and mass diffusion. For pure IrO2 catalysts with a smaller specific surface area, the relationship between catalyst usage and electrolyzer performance is controlled by ohmic resistance. As the catalyst loading increases, the conductivity of the catalyst layer improves, resulting in better electrolyzer performance (Fig. 6(a) , left) [39]. In contrast, for IrO2/Ti systems formed by physically mixing larger surface area nano-titanium powder with IrO2, the relationship between catalyst usage and electrolyzer performance is controlled by diffusion resistance. As catalyst loading increases, the performance of the electrolyzers worsens (Fig. 6(a), right) [39]. Nafion ionomer content in the anode catalyst layer affects catalyst performance expression (Fig. 4(b) ) [40]. Nafion ionomer acts as a binder for the catalyst and a proton conductor; however, it is non-conductive, leading to a need for a balanced amount in the catalyst layer. Excessive Nafion ionomer would cause insulation and separation of active sites, while too little would result in catalyst particle detachment and hinder proton transfer. The thickness of the proton exchange membrane significantly impacts the evaluation of performance. Therefore, consistency in the thickness of the proton exchange membrane used for the performance evaluation of oxygen evolution catalysts must be ensured [44]. As shown in Fig. 4(c), as the membrane thickness decreases from Nafion 117 (~183 μm) to Nafion 115 (~127 μm) and Nafion 212 (~50 μm), performance changes significantly [41]. After iR correction, the three performance curves nearly overlap, indicating that membrane thickness affects internal resistance and, consequently, performance. The coating on the porous transport layer of the anode in a PEMWE electrolyzer can influence performance by affecting the contact resistance between the catalyst particles and the transport layer. As shown in Fig. 4(d), Pt-coated titanium felt outperforms bare, gold-coated, or iridium-coated titanium felt in performance [42]. Furthermore, the Pt coating is more cost-effective than gold or iridium, which is why most reports use Pt-coated titanium felt as the porous transport layer for the anode. The testing temperature of the PEMWE electrolyzers also affects their performance [45,46]. As shown in Fig. 4(e), under typical conditions (below the boiling point of water), higher testing temperatures generally result in better reaction activity and better electrolyzer performance [43]. Many reports in the literature use 80 °C as the testing temperature for iridium-based catalysts. When evaluating the lifespan of oxygen evolution catalysts using the stability of the PEMWE electrolyzers, it is crucial to consider the influence of factors in the PEMWE electrolyzers other than the catalyst itself. As the catalyst loading increases, the stability of the catalyst layer structure and conductivity improve, leading to better catalytic stability. As shown in Fig. 5(a) , with increasing catalyst loading, the voltage decay rate of the electrolyzers decreases, showing a trend of enhanced stability [47]. The thickness of the proton exchange membrane also significantly impacts performance. A thinner Nafion 212 membrane is prone to gas permeation, exacerbating performance degradation. In contrast, a thicker Nafion 117 membrane has a higher internal resistance, resulting in higher driving voltage under the same current density, which accelerates the degradation of the catalyst and components. In comparison, the Nafion 115 membrane, with moderate thickness, balances both performance and stability. As shown in Fig. 5(b), Nafion 115 exhibits the best stability among the three membranes [41]. The local accumulation of bubbles interferes with stability [50]. As shown in Fig. 5(c), in constant voltage tests of oxygen evolution catalysts, if the voltage supply is disconnected after 24 h, and the electrolyte flow is maintained, the performance of the electrolyzers does not improve [48]. However, if the voltage supply is disconnected and the electrolyzer is dried, the performance nearly recovers to the level at the start of the stability test, strongly proving the performance impact of bubble interference. The coating on the titanium felt significantly affects the electrolyzer performance. Bare titanium felt requires a higher driving voltage compared to Pt-coated titanium felt (Fig. 5(d)), which leads to faster degradation of the catalyst and components, hindering the evaluation of the catalyst’s stability [42]. Impurities from catalysts, titanium components, and the water supply, including metal ions, can poison the proton exchange membrane to varying degrees. As shown in Fig. 5(e), after poisoning with sodium ions, the proton conductivity of the membrane decreases, and the polarization curve performance significantly worsens compared to the fresh, non-poisoned membrane [49]. This highlights the necessity of controlling the metal ion concentration in the water environment on the anode side of the proton exchange membrane to achieve high stability in electrolyzer performance. 2.3 Catalytic and dissolution mechanisms To rationally design iridium-based catalysts, it is essential to understand the specific mechanisms of the OER catalyzed by iridium-based catalysts. Unlike the oxygen evolution reaction in alkaline systems, the OER catalyzed by PEMWE catalysts can be referred to as an acidic oxygen evolution reaction [34]. Three widely accepted mechanisms for the acidic OER on iridium-based catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 6: Adsorption-desorption mechanism (AEM), lattice oxygen oxidation mechanism (LOM), and oxide pathway mechanism (OPM) [51–53]. AEM, the first proposed acidic oxygen evolution mechanism, suggests that the reaction occurs at a single-site level. In this mechanism, the metal active site (Ir) in state 1 interacts with the hydroxyl group of dissociated water, forming state 2. State 2 undergoes deprotonation to become state 3, which then reacts with dissociated hydroxyl groups to form state 4. In state 4, oxygen is evolved, and deprotonation leads the system back to state 1. Each of these four steps involves the simultaneous transfer of protons and electrons, ensuring that the generation of protons at the anode precisely corresponds to the consumption of protons at the cathode, which are converted into hydrogen gas. This allows the reaction to only consume water without altering the pH. Following AEM, the LOM was proposed, where lattice oxygen plays a role in the reaction. LOM is further divided into two sub-mechanisms: LOM-1, which involves a single lattice oxygen, and LOM-2, which involves two lattice oxygens. Using isotope labeling with 18O, LOM-1 can only detect 34O2 gas through differential electrochemical mass spectrometry, whereas LOM-2 can detect 36O2 gas. In the LOM-1 pathway, the transition from state 1 to state 3 shares similarities with AEM, but in state 3, lattice oxygen directly interacts with the reaction, forming an oxygen vacancy that leads to state 5. Oxygen evolution occurs from state 5 to state 6, and state 6 to state 7 involves the hydroxyl group from water filling the oxygen vacancy. State 2 then deprotonates and returns to state 1. In the LOM-2 pathway, a significant difference arises where oxygen sites adjacent to iridium atoms act as the active adsorption sites, rather than iridium itself. In this pathway, state 1 undergoes lattice oxygen migration and adsorption to become state 8, which then evolves oxygen to create an oxygen vacancy, transitioning to state 9. The hydroxyl group from water fills the vacancy adjacent to the iridium site, forming state 10. This process involves the dehydrogenation of the hydroxyl group to form lattice oxygen, followed by further dehydrogenation to return to states 6 and 7, and ultimately back to state 1. Following LOM, the OPM gained widespread attention through in-situ infrared studies identifying state 12 [54,55]. In contrast to AEM and LOM, OPM involves two metal sites in the reaction pathway. In this mechanism, state 13 involves the deprotonation of a hydroxyl group on one metal site and the adsorption of a hydroxyl group on another, transitioning to state 14. State 14 undergoes further deprotonation to become state 11, which is shared with both AEM and LOM-1 (state 3). When the two metal sites are sufficiently close, state 11 can transition to state 12 through the coupling of oxygen atoms at both metal sites. State 12 then evolves oxygen and returns to state 13 through hydroxyl group adsorption. In a 2011 paper by Rossmeisl et al. [56], a detailed analysis of the four elementary steps in the AEM pathway was conducted based on density functional theory (DFT) calculations. In Fig. 7(a) , they calculated the free energy barriers of these four elementary steps under standard conditions (pH = 0, T = 25 °C). The rate-determining step (RDS) of the AEM pathway is the elementary step featuring the highest free energy barrier, and the theoretical oxygen evolution overpotential (η OER) for the acidic oxygen evolution reaction can be calculated using the free energy barrier of the RDS, corresponding to the theoretical value of η a in Eq. (5). Unfortunately, their calculations showed that the adsorption strength of oxygenated species on the active site follows a linear constraint relationship (Fig. 7(b)), specifically with the difference between ΔG HO* and ΔG HOO* being nearly constant at 3.2 eV. Due to this linear constraint on the adsorption energies of the oxygen species, the η OER based on the AEM pathway has a minimum theoretical value of 0.37 V, and there exists a volcano-shaped relationship between η OER and the adsorption strength of oxygen species, as shown in Fig. 7(c). In the volcano curve, IrO2 is positioned on the left side of the curve, indicating that the bonding strength of the Ir–O bond is too strong compared to the optimal binding strength. To reach the peak of the volcano curve, the Ir–O bond strength needs to be appropriately weakened, which corresponds to an increase in the bond length of the Ir–O bond. After the AEM pathway, the calculations for LOM and OPM are mostly based on the framework developed by Jan Rossmeisl et al. [56] and are designed and improved upon from there. By identifying the RDS of complex elementary steps or comparing the RDS between different pathways, the minimum η OER for the catalytic system and the optimal theoretical reaction pathway can be derived. Alongside catalytic reactions, iridium-based dissolution reactions often occur, which dynamically affect the catalytic activity and stability of the catalyst. Fig. 7(d) shows the possible dissolution pathways of iridium and the associated dissolution elementary reactions [57]. Ir metal is irreversibly oxidized to form IrO2 (S2), a process that involves the conversion from zero-valent iridium to four-valent iridium and the dissolution of trivalent Ir3+ ions (S1). IrO2 undergoes hydration to form IrO2OH (S3), and this hydrated species further oxidizes to form a five-valent iridium species, IrO2OH(S4). When the applied oxidation voltage is relatively low, IrO2OH may release oxygen and reduce to a trivalent iridium species, HIrO2 (S5), which may either dissolve as Ir3+ ions (S6) or re-oxidize to IrO2 (S7). When the applied oxidation voltage is sufficiently high, IrO2OH may continue to oxidize to form a six-valent iridium species, IrO3 (S8). IrO3 may either release oxygen and reduce back to IrO2 (S9) or dissolve as IrO4 2– ions (S10). Based on the dissolution pathways shown, it can be inferred that the four-valent iridium state in iridium oxide is likely the most stable oxidation state, and when four-valent iridium is reduced to a lower-valent state or oxidized to higher-valent iridium, this may induce some degree of dissolution and lead to the surface reconstruction of the catalyst. These microscale reaction mechanisms underpin the macroscopic dissolution process in acidic OER, which can be systematically outlined via a three-step framework: (a) Initial chemical dissolution (no or low external voltage): When Ir-based catalysts are first immersed in acidic electrolytes (such as H2SO4 solution), initial chemical dissolution occurs even without external voltage. In the acidic environment, high-concentration H+ attacks the Ir–O bonds on the catalyst surface, causing protonation of Ir–O bonds, reduction of bond energy and subsequent fracture. Ir slowly dissolves as low-valence ions (e.g., Ir3+, Ir4+) [58,59]. Meanwhile, Ir atoms at surface defects (vacancies, dislocations, etc.) generated during catalyst preparation, due to low coordination numbers and high energy, are easily attacked by H+ and dissolved. At this stage, dissolution is slow with small amounts of Ir released. (b) Peroxidation-accelerated dissolution (electrochemical oxidation dominated): When voltage is applied to enter the OER potential range (> 1.23 V vs. RHE), the dissolution rate increases sharply, due to the synergy of peroxidation and electrochemical driving. At low voltages (such as 1.23–1.4 V vs. RHE), the electric field drives electrochemical oxidation of Ir atoms, transforming them from low valence (e.g., Ir4+) to high valence (e.g., Ir5+) [60]. High-valence Ir oxide species have poor chemical stability and their interaction with H⁺ makes Ir-O bonds more prone to fracture, increasing the dissolution rate severalfold. At higher voltages (such as > 1.5 V vs. RHE), accelerated OER reactions cause Ir atoms to undergo peroxidation and lattice distortion due to participation in reactions (AEM/LOM/OPM mechanisms) [61]. Moreover, potential cycling intensifies the lattice stress accumulation-release process, making Ir atoms detach from the lattice, leading to exponential-growth dissolution. (c) Post-dissolution dynamics: Dissolved Ir ions may redeposit in-situ to form new oxide layers. However, voltage fluctuations and acidic erosion cause redissolution of these new layers, resulting in loss of active sites [62]. If the electrolyte contains Cl– (as a contaminant ion), Ir ions form stable complexes (e.g., [IrCl6]2–) that irreversibly leach out, accelerating catalyst deactivation [63]. 3 Iridium-based catalysts classification 3.1 Metal/hydroxide/oxide Iridium inevitably interacts with oxygen atoms and hydroxyl groups during the oxygen evolution process, leading to iridium oxidation and hydroxylation. Based on these working conditions, we can categorize iridium metal, iridium hydroxide, and iridium oxide into a major category for detailed research and analysis. Mayrhofer et al. [64] used atom probe tomography to study the structural evolution of iridium metal under oxygen evolution conditions. As shown in Fig. 8(a) , the iridium metal surface first transforms into a loose, non-stoichiometric Ir-O oxide layer under oxidation, and water molecules and hydroxyl groups can penetrate this loose oxide layer. With sufficient oxidation time, the loose oxide layer gradually transitions into a dense IrO2 oxide layer (with a stoichiometric ratio of iridium and oxygen of 1:2). Since the non-stoichiometric Ir-O oxide layer has higher activity but lower stability, and the dense IrO2 oxide layer has lower activity but better stability, this oxidation transformation of iridium metal results in a decrease in iridium metal activity and an enhancement in its stability [70]. Yang et al. [65] designed electrochemically exfoliated H x IrO3 hydroxide nanosheets based on a layered compound α-Li2IrO3 (Fig. 8(b)). α-Li2IrO3 undergoes electrochemical exfoliation in 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4, resulting in proton (H+) intercalated H x IrO3, which is further exfoliated by larger TMA+ ions produced by tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH). The obtained H x IrO3 nanosheets exhibit a clear diffraction peak at the (001) crystal face, indicating that the exposed crystal face of the nanosheets is the (001) face. Hong et al. [66] used a salt-template method to prepare amorphous iridium oxide nanosheets (Fig. 8(c)). This catalyst exhibited a performance of 1.67 V @ 1 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with an Nafion 115 membrane (approximately 127 μm thick, abbreviated as N115) at 80 °C and remained stable at a current density of 1 A cm–2 for 120 h. Schlögl et al. [67] conducted a detailed study of the structural characteristics of rutile-type iridium oxide. As shown in Fig. 8(d), the diffraction peak of the low θ angle (110) crystal face of rutile-type iridium oxide is the strongest. This indicates that the interplanar spacing of the (110) crystal face is large, the atomic arrangement is regular, and the atomic density is high. Such crystal faces often exhibit lower surface energy, making the (110) crystal face a common exposed face for rutile-type iridium oxide catalysts, as reported in various studies. Shao et al. [68] used a self-made microwave-assisted mechanical thermal reactor to synthesize metastable 3R-type iridium oxide nanosheets (Fig. 8(e)). The authors proposed that the edge-sharing structure of 3R-IrO2, coupled with proton transport channels from iridium vacancies, enhances catalytic activity. In the same year, they designed a non-microwave-assisted self-made mechanical thermal reactor and synthesized another metastable phase material, 1T-type iridium oxide nanosheets (Fig. 8(f)) [69]. In contrast to the (0003) crystal face primarily exposed to 3R-IrO2, the (0001) crystal face is predominantly exposed to 1T-IrO2. These two metastable-phase iridium oxides exhibit higher activity than rutile-type iridium oxide due to their unique crystal structures, but further experimental evidence is needed to confirm whether their surface structures transition to the more stable rutile phase at high current densities. 3.2 Doped Doped oxygen evolution catalysts of iridium-based systems (including iridium metal, iridium hydroxides, and iridium oxides) that introduce elements other than hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O) can be classified into a broad category. The introduced dopants can be categorized into two groups based on their impact on the oxygen evolution activity: active element doping and non-active element doping. Among these, other oxygen evolution active elements introduced into iridium-based systems include Ru [71–73], Mn [74–76], Co [77–79], and Ni [80–82]. Iridium-ruthenium (Ir-Ru) alloy oxides are the most studied case. Ru shows higher OER activity than Ir but lacks stability at high current densities [83–85]. Introducing a small amount of Ru into the structurally stable iridium oxide lattice can enhance oxygen evolution activity while maintaining good stability. Aricò et al. [86] prepared an Ir0.7Ru0.3O x catalyst (Fig. 9(a) ) using an improved Adams fusion method. This catalyst, when used in a PEMWE electrolyzer with an Aquivion membrane (thickness ~85 μm) at 80 °C, demonstrated activity of approximately 1.852 V @ 3 A cm–2 with a catalyst loading of 0.4 mgcat cm–2. It also exhibited stable operation at 3 A cm–2 for 1000 h, with a voltage decay rate of 23 μV h–1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the anode catalyst layer after the stability test revealed the presence of Ru, indicating that Ru remained stable after prolonged high current density operation. Compared to traditional iridium-ruthenium oxides, iridium-manganese oxides have gained increasing attention in recent research. Zhang et al. [87] synthesized the Mn0.15Ir0.85O2–σ catalyst (Fig. 9(b)) using the Adams fusion method. They found that under applied bias, the oxidation of manganese produced a significant pseudocapacitance in the potential region before the oxygen evolution reaction, which enhanced the oxygen evolution kinetics at the iridium sites. This catalyst demonstrated activity of 1.637 V @ 2 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with Nafion 212 membrane (thickness ~50 μm, abbreviated as N212 or NR212) at 80 °C. It operated stably for 800 h at 2 A cm–2 with a voltage decay rate of 19.4 μV h–1. For non-active dopant elements, elements that are prone to dissolution at high current densities (such as alkali metals [92], rare earth elements [93], etc.) or elements that are less soluble at high current densities (such as titanium [94–96], niobium [89,97], tantalum [98,99], gold [100], etc.) can be introduced. Wang et al. introduced soluble Sr into iridium oxide (Fig. 9(c)) [88]. Acid treatment during the synthesis process caused the dissolution of unstable Sr species, leaving behind stable Sr species. This catalyst exhibited an activity of 1.72 V @ 1 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with Nafion 117 membrane (thickness ~183 μm, abbreviated as N117) at 80 °C, and it operated stably for over 500 h at 1 A cm–2. Lu et al. [89] introduced the less soluble element Nb into 1T-IrO₂ to prepare the Nb0.05Ir0.95O2 catalyst (shown in Fig. 9(d)). This catalyst demonstrated activity of 1.634 V @ 1 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with Nafion NR211 membrane (thickness ~25 μm) at 60 °C, and it operated stably for 1200 h at around 1.2 A cm–2. In addition to introducing metal elements into iridium oxide, non-metallic elements have also been reported. Hu et al. [90] incorporated boron (B) into iridium oxide nanoneedles to prepare a B-IrO2 catalyst. Compared to undoped iridium oxide nanoneedles (L-IrO2) and iridium oxide nanoparticles synthesized by the Adams fusion method (A-IrO2), the XPS signals of the B-IrO2 catalyst after water washing showed a distinct peak corresponding to borates (Fig. (6)), indicating the presence of insoluble B species in the catalyst. This catalyst demonstrated stable operation for 160 h at a current density of 1 A cm–2 with a catalyst loading of 0.08 mgIr cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with Nafion 117 membrane at room temperature. Rather than homogeneous bulk doping, Xing et al. [91] proposed a unique reverse doping strategy for surface doping (Fig. 9(f)). Specifically, using TiB2 as a sacrificial template, Ti atoms were enriched on the surface of the IrO x /Ir substrate for surface doping. In three-electrode testing, the introduction of just 1.92 wt% titanium increased the intrinsic activity by a factor of 3.6 and improved stability by an order of magnitude. This catalyst exhibited an activity of 1.774 V @ 2 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, and it operated stably for over 200 h at 1 A cm–2, with both activity and stability outperforming undoped samples. 3.3 Supported The introduction of elements other than hydrogen (H) and oxygen (O) as dispersion carriers into iridium-based systems (including iridium metal, iridium hydroxides, and iridium oxides) can be classified into a major category of oxygen evolution catalysts. Iridium, the active component, forms a well-defined heterogeneous interface with the support material [101,102]. In the PEMWE electrolyzers, conductive carbon-based supports are prone to oxidation into CO2, leading to the detachment of active sites and rendering the catalyst unusable. Consequently, the primary support materials used in PEMWE include dissolution-resistant oxides [103–105], borides [106], carbides [107], and nitrides [108], all of which exhibit significantly lower electrical conductivity than iridium metal and iridium oxides. For metallic compound supports other than oxides, an inevitable thin layer of surface oxide forms when exposed to air or oxidative conditions in water electrolysis. This necessitates that iridium species rely on their inherent conductivity to establish an efficient electrical network on the support surface. Among various support materials, titanium oxide (TiO2) and niobium oxide (Nb2O5) are the most commonly used. Yang et al. [109] first synthesized the H2Ti6O13 precursor via a hydrothermal method, followed by mixing it with an iridium precursor and employing the Adams fusion method to obtain the IrO2/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 10(a) ). The catalyst surface exhibited a high concentration of hydroxyl species, imparting excellent hydrophilicity. In a PEMWE electrolyzer with a Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, the catalyst demonstrated an activity of 1.787 V @ 2 A cm–2 and operated stably at 1 A cm–2 for 350 h, with a voltage degradation rate of ~300 μV h–1. Xing et al. [110] utilized an ethylene glycol reduction method to deposit iridium metal onto a concentrated HCl-treated Nb2O5–x support, synthesizing the Ir/Nb2O5–x catalyst (Fig. 10(b)). The study showed that oxygen from oxidatively formed IrO3 species migrates to support oxygen vacancies, inhibiting IrO3 dissolution and improving stability. In a PEMWE electrolyzer with a Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, this catalyst exhibited an activity of 1.839 V @ 3 A cm–2 and maintained stable operation at 2 A cm–2 for 2000 h, with no observable voltage degradation. Compared to single-metal oxide supports, Zhang et al. [111] synthesized a Zr1Ta10O x composite support by high-temperature reduction of mixed ZrO2 and Ta2O5, followed by an ethylene glycol reflux reaction to reduce iridium metal onto the composite surface, yielding the Ir-ZrTaO x catalyst (Fig. 10(c)). This catalyst demonstrated activity of ~1.83 V @ 2 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with a Nafion 117 membrane at 80 °C and exhibited stable operation at 1 A cm–2 for over 200 h, with a voltage decay rate of 4.7 μV h–1. Beyond pure oxide supports, Zou et al. [112] synthesized TaB nanorod supports, observing a native TaO x surface layer of less than 2 nm. Using the Adams fusion method, iridium oxide was deposited on the nanorods, increasing the TaO x layer thickness to approximately 10 nm, resulting in the IrO2@TaO x @TaB catalyst (Fig. 10(d)). In a PEMWE electrolyzer with a Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, this catalyst exhibited an activity of 1.9 V @ 3 A cm–2 and maintained stability at 2 A cm–2 for 1000 h, with a voltage degradation rate of 6.8 μV h–1. While stable oxide interfaces are preferred, research has also explored oxide interfaces with relatively lower acid stability [115,116]. Zhang et al. [113] developed the RIE-Ir/CeO x catalyst using a ripening-induced embedding (RIE) strategy (Fig. 10(e)). In a PEMWE electrolyzer at 80 °C, this catalyst demonstrated an activity of 1.72 V @ 3 A cm–2 and exhibited a voltage decay rate of 1.33 μV h-1 at 3 A cm–2. Luo et al. [114] synthesized MnO2 nanowire supports via a hydrothermal method and subsequently deposited IrO₂ using the Adams fusion method to obtain the IrO2/MnO2 catalyst (Fig. 10(f)). This catalyst demonstrated an activity of 1.89 V @ 2 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer with a Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C and maintained stable operation at 1 A cm–2 for 100 h, with a voltage decay rate of 100 μV h–1. The OER mechanism of supported iridium catalysts (typical heterogeneous systems) can be complicated by oxygen spillover involving oxygen-containing species (e.g., lattice O2–, adsorbed *OH/*O/*OOH intermediates) between supports and Ir active sites. Fundamentally, oxygen spillover represents directional migration of oxygen species, sharing mechanistic similarities with LOM or dual-site pathways in doped catalysts. The specific reaction mechanisms involving oxygen spillover require refinement based on the identity of migrating oxygen species, spillover directionality, and resultant modulation of conventional pathways (AEM/LOM/OPM). For instance, Ren et al. [116] reported Ir@Ga2O3 where Ga3+-OH groups dissociate under bias to form mobile *OH that migrates to adjacent Ir sites. In-situ XPS revealed diminished Ga3+-OH intensity beyond 1.25 V, indicating *OH migration from Ga sites, while DFT calculations showed lower migration energy (1.85 eV) than desorption energy (2.60 eV), favoring *OH spillover. These observations support a modified two-site co-AEM mechanism facilitated by *OH spillover (Fig. 11(a) ). Such hydroxyl migration likely stabilizes Ir sites by filling lattice defects, consistent with Ir L3-edge XANES showing stable Ir4+ valence under high bias. This catalyst achieved 1.76 V @ 2 A cm–2 in PEMWE (Nafion 212, 80 °C) and operated stably for ∼1000 h @ 1 A cm–2 with 11.5 μV h-1 decay. Current understanding identifies two stabilization modes via oxygen spillover: (a) Reverse spillover (oxygen-deficient IrO x → oxygen-rich Metal-Oxide, MO x ): As exemplified by the Ir/Nb-doped TiO2 in Cheng et al.’s report (Fig. 11(b)), *OH migrates from Ir sites to oxygen vacancies on supports, preventing Ir overoxidation [117]. In-situ Raman showed attenuated Ir-OHad (660–680 cm–1) and blue-shifted E g vibrations of Ti-O, signifying *OH migration and vacancy filling. The DFT confirmed lower reverse spillover barriers with oxygen vacancies (0.43 vs. 0.60 eV without vacancies). This catalyst delivered 1.69 V @ 1 A cm–2 (Nafion 115, 65 °C) with 40 μV h–1 decay over 500 h @ 1 A cm–2. Similar reverse spillover is documented in Ir/SnO2:Sb [118], Ir/Nb2O5–x [110], RuO2/MoO3 [119], and RuO2/Nb2O5 [120]. (b) Forward spillover (oxygen-rich Metal-Oxide, MO x → oxygen-deficient IrO x ): Yang et al.’s IrO x /t-ZrO2 (Fig. 11(c)) demonstrates oxygen species generated via water dissociation on t-ZrO2 spill over to replenish lattice oxygen vacancies in IrOₓ, inhibiting dissolution of Ir [121]. Operando XAFS showed stable Ir valence (1.5–1.7 V), reduced Zr valence, and dynamic recovery of Ir–O bond lengths, evidencing oxygen migration from Zr to Ir sites. The DFT revealed low water dissociation barriers on t-ZrO2, enabling efficient oxygen supply. This catalyst achieved 1.9 V @ 2.39 A cm–2 (Nafion 115, 80 °C) and operated stably for 1600 h @ 1 A cm–2. The aforementioned Ir@Ga2O3 also follows forward spillover. Critically, both stabilization modes operate via bias-driven directional oxygen transport at high potentials, whereas spillover directionality may reverse at lower potentials [110]. 3.4 Special crystal structures Dopant-induced compounds with unique crystal structures constitute a major category of OER catalysts. Wang et al. [122] synthesized a catalyst, KIr4O8, with a special crystal structure (Fig. 12(a) ). The KIr4O8 crystal consists of KO4 at the corner positions and IrO6 at the central position. This catalyst exhibits an activity of 1.68 V at 1 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer using Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C and shows stable operation for 1230 h at a current density of 1 A cm-2. Iridium-containing compounds with perovskite structures have been extensively studied in three-electrode systems; however, due to their structural instability, research on such catalysts in the PEMWE electrolyzers has been limited [123–125]. As shown in Fig. 12(b), the structure of a single perovskite is represented by ABO3, while a double perovskite has the structure A2BB’O6 [126]. Zhang et al. [127] reported a B-site doped single perovskite SrTi0.25Ir0.75O3 catalyst (Fig. 12(c)), which exhibited an activity of approximately 1.94 V at 1 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer using Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, and demonstrated stable operation for 100 h at a current density of 0.5 A cm–2. Rojas et al. [128] reported a double perovskite Sr2CaIrO6 catalyst (Fig. 12(d)), which showed an activity of 1.81 V at 2 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer using Nafion 212 membrane at 80 °C, with stable operation for 450 h at 2 A cm–2. The authors found that after the dissolution of Sr and Ca, the catalyst formed a hollow structure of IrO6 octahedral clusters. 3.5 Special morphological structures Controlling the morphology of Ir-based catalysts through specialized preparation methods and conditions enables the fabrication of diverse structures, including zero-dimensional nanoparticles, one-dimensional nanowires, two-dimensional nanosheets, and three-dimensional nanonetworks. For PEMWE applications, however, the ideal structure of iridium-based catalysts must balance electrical conductivity and stability with maximizing active site exposure and generating highly intrinsic active sites. Zou et al. [129] reported a hollow nanospheres-structured IrO x catalyst (Fig. 13(a) ) synthesized via SiO2 hard-templating, Ir(OH)3 shell deposition, calcination, and template etching. The catalyst achieved 1.9 V @ 3.3 A cm–2 in a PEMWE using Nafion 115 at 80 °C and maintained stability for ~1000 h at 2 A cm–2. Shao et al. [100] reported a nanoribbons-structured Au-doped IrO2 catalyst (Fig. 13(b)) prepared via K2CO3-assisted synthesis under high-temperature (700 °C) and mechanical stirring. Intriguingly, the catalyst exhibited a monoclinic crystal phase, though its PEMWE performance was suboptimal, potentially due to experimental setup or harsh synthesis conditions. Peron et al. [130] reported a highly porous Ir0.7Ru0.3O2 catalyst (Fig. 13(c)) fabricated by spray-drying and calcining a mixture of Ir/Ru precursors with poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA). The catalyst achieved 1.656 V @ 1 A cm–2 in a PEMWE with Nafion 115 at 80 °C and maintained stability for ~44 h at 1 A cm–2. Zou et al. [131] reported a nanosheets-structured H x IrO y catalyst (Fig. 13(d)) synthesized by acid-leaching K and Na from K0.5(Na0.2Ir0.8)O2, followed by tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) intercalation. The catalyst achieved 2 V @ 3.8 A cm–2 in a PEMWE with Nafion 115 at 80 °C and demonstrated 400 h of stability at 1 A cm–2. In contrast to powder-based catalysts, self-supporting architectures eliminate binders to expose active sites. Jung et al. reported a woodpile-structured Ir catalyst fabricated via thin-film deposition, photolithography, and transfer techniques [132]. The catalyst achieved ~1.76 V @ 2 A cm–2 in a PEMWE with Nafion 212 at 80 °C but only maintained stability for 45 h at 0.1 A cm–2, highlighting the need for high-current durability testing. 4 Preparation and characterization of iridium-based catalysts 4.1 Preparation methods According to the currently published literature, iridium-based oxygen evolution catalysts typically involve three forms of iridium during their preparation process: iridium oxide, iridium metal, and other solid forms of iridium (such as hydroxides, gels, and other precipitates). The first two forms of iridium species are acid-resistant and can generally be used directly in the PEMWE electrolyzers, while the third form usually requires further oxidation to iridium oxide or reduction to iridium metal. Based on this understanding, common preparation methods for iridium-based catalysts are categorized and shown in Fig. 14 . For the preparation of iridium oxides (IrO2/IrO x ), common methods include: (a) Adams fusion method: Sodium nitrate (melting point 308 °C) or potassium nitrate (melting point 334 °C) in molten salt above their melting points oxidizes iridium precursors [133–135]. (b) Direct calcination in the air: The precursor is converted to an oxide by the oxygen components in the air at temperatures higher than its pyrolysis temperature [136]. (c) Salt template method: The precursor is dispersed on salt crystals (such as NaCl), and the iridium precursor is decomposed into oxide at temperatures below the salt’s melting point, after which the salt template is washed away to yield the product [66,137,138]. For the preparation of iridium metal (Ir), common methods include: (a) Ethylene glycol reduction method: The reducibility of ethylene glycol is utilized to reduce iridium precursors (such as IrCl3, H2IrCl6, Ir(acac)3) to iridium metal at temperatures typically ranging from 140 to 200 °C. The reduced iridium metal forms an IrO x oxide layer when exposed to water or air surfaces [139–141]. (b) Hydrogen reduction method: Iridium precursors are typically reduced to iridium metal under high-temperature conditions using hydrogen [142]. (c) Electrolytic reduction method: This approach typically involves constructing a three-electrode system and employing an electrolyte containing iridium salts. Upon applying a reductive potential, iridium ions are reduced to metallic iridium (Ir0) and subsequently deposited onto a conductive substrate, such as a titanium mesh or titanium felt. For the preparation of other solid forms of iridium, common methods include: (a) Sol-gel method: Iridium salts are complexed with ligands (such as citric acid or ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid), the pH of the solution is adjusted to form sol particles, and the gel precipitate is obtained. The gel is then calcined to produce iridium oxide or iridium metal [143,144]. (b) Hydrothermal method: Iridium salts, water, and precipitating agents (alkaline environments facilitate precipitation) are mixed and subjected to high-temperature, high-pressure reactions in a hydrothermal reactor. The obtained precipitate often requires calcination to enhance the catalyst’s stability [145]. (c) Alkaline hydrolysis method (at atmospheric pressure): The reaction is similar to the hydrothermal method, except it is conducted at atmospheric pressure in a glass container. The crystallinity of the precipitate is typically lower than that obtained by the hydrothermal method, and the surface properties and specific surface area differ between the two methods [146]. 4.2 Conventional characterization techniques For PEMWE iridium-based catalysts, three-electrode testing preliminarily evaluates activity and stability, serving as a catalyst pre-screening tool. Subsequently, activity and stability tests at high current densities are conducted in the PEMWE electrolyzers. Once the catalyst performance meets the desired requirements, further characterization is performed to assess the crystalline phase structure, morphology, electronic structure, and other relevant properties. Specifically, conventional characterization techniques include: (a) Three-electrode testing: Cyclic voltammetry (CV) is typically used for catalyst activation [147]. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) is commonly used to determine the oxygen evolution overpotential, and through data transformation, the Tafel slope, as shown in Fig. 15(a) , can be evaluated to assess the reaction rate [148]. Electrochemical surface area (ECSA) can be roughly calculated by performing CV at potentials where oxygen evolution does not occur, at various scan rates. The LSV data can be normalized to ECSA to compare the intrinsic activity of catalysts [149]. Chronoamperometry (CA) is typically used to evaluate stability at a specified voltage, while chronopotentiometry (CP) is commonly employed to assess stability at a specified current density. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is widely used to analyze the charge transfer resistance on the electrode surface [150]. (b) PEMWE electrolyzers testing: Polarization curves are used to obtain the driving voltage at a specified current density [151]. Stability testing is prevalent in the literature, where most studies observe voltage decay at a specified current density [152]. Various internal resistance breakdown tests are also applied, such as those shown in Fig. 15(b), where Bender et al. [153] utilized internal resistance testing and calculations to decompose the polarization curve into Nernst potential, activation overpotential, ohmic overpotential, and diffusion overpotential. (c) Crystalline phase structure testing: X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterizes the bulk crystalline structure of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 15(c), XRD refinement requires more precise signal acquisition compared to conventional XRD and involves fitting the data based on specific structural models [122]. (d) Morphological testing: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is typically suitable for observing the microstructure and particle size of the catalyst [129]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as shown in Fig. 15(d), allows for observing fine lattice spacing and morphology due to electrons passing through the sample [154]. However, the sample must be thin for effective observation; otherwise, only the outline of the catalyst will be visible. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) is frequently used for observing the thickness of iridium-based catalyst nanosheets and the surface structure of the anode catalyst layer [157,158]. (e) Electronic structure testing: XPS, as shown in Fig. 15(e), provides the valence state signals on the catalyst surface, and through peak fitting, the content of various valence states can be compared [155]. X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS), as shown in Fig. 15(f), allows for comparing the average valence state signals of the bulk phase of the catalyst [156]. Further fitting based on the catalyst’s structural model provides detailed information such as atomic distances and coordination numbers [150]. 4.3 Emerging in-situ characterization techniques Compared to conventional testing methods, emerging in-situ techniques allow for the characterization of catalysts in their true state during the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Common emerging in-situ characterization techniques include: (a) differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) (Fig. 16(a) ). Coupled with 18O isotope labeling, this technique enables the in-situ detection of oxygen signals with varying molecular masses generated during the OER. It can be used to deduce whether lattice oxygen participates in the reaction and to infer the reaction pathway [159]. (b) In-situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy (Fig. 16(b)). This method detects the changes in infrared vibrational signals of various adsorbed oxygen species during the OER process [160]. (c) In-situ XRD (Fig. 16(c)). Despite the in-situ cell being in an open-circuit state after voltage application, this technique can effectively track changes in the crystalline phase structure of the catalyst during the reaction [161]. (d) In-situ XPS (Fig. 16(d)). This technique analyzes the changes in the surface concentration of different oxidation states of species under voltage-driven conditions [162]. (e) In-situ XAFS (Fig. 16(e)). XAFS can provide insights into the trends of overall oxidation state changes and the variations in fine structural information driven by voltage changes [163]. (f) In-situ Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 16(f)). This technique analyzes the shifts in Raman vibrational peaks corresponding to Ir–O bonds in the catalyst under varying driving voltages [164]. (g) In-situ TEM (Fig. 16(g)). A quasi-in-situ IL-TEM technique can determine the same location before and after the OER, allowing for the tracking of morphological and structural changes in the catalyst [128]. 5 Design strategies for iridium-based catalysts 5.1 Design principles for cost-performance co-optimization The practical application of iridium-based catalysts in PEMWE electrolysis cells requires consideration of cost issues. Unfortunately, directly reducing the usage of iridium-based catalysts will alter the performance of the electrolyzer. Therefore, constructing a correlation analysis model between the cost and performance of iridium-based catalysts is necessary for their integrated design. To establish a cost-performance collaborative design framework for iridium-based catalysts, we assume that the mathematical model of the anode catalyst layer in PEMWE is an idealized cuboid (Fig. 17(a) ). The model is externally divided into the membrane area (l1 ×l2 ) and membrane thickness (d). The interior of the model includes the catalyst, binder Nafion, and pores not occupied by the catalyst and binder, with their volume fractions denoted as φ cat, φ Nafion, and φ pores, respectively. These three parameters can correlate the catalyst mass (m cat), catalyst density (ρ cat), and the entire volume (V) of catalyst layer at anode. Accordingly, the mass of iridium (m Ir) in the anode catalyst layer can be derived from the m cat and the mass percentage of iridium in the catalyst (f Ir). The m Ir normalized to unit area, i.e., loading(Ir), is positively correlated with the usage cost of iridium-based catalysts. Controlling this value is central to cost management of iridium-based catalysts in PEMWE, as a smaller loading(Ir) indicates reduced consumption of noble metals and lower costs. To balance cost and performance, mathematical analysis of electrolyzer performance is required, as shown in Fig. 17(b). The model calculates under the most common testing conditions for PEMWE electrolyzers (80 °C and 1 atm), yielding a theoretically corrected water-electrolysis overpotential of 1.183 V [165]. Based on this theoretical value, the actual water electrolysis overpotential can ultimately be decomposed into the sum of the following components: theoretical water electrolysis overpotential (1.183 V), cathode overpotential (η c), cathode diffusion overpotential (η diff,c), ionic resistance overpotential of the cathode catalyst layer ( i R CL,c ion ), electronic resistance overpotential of the cathode catalyst layer ( i R CL,c elec ), anode overpotential (η a), anode diffusion overpotential (η diff,a), ionic resistance overpotential of the anode catalyst layer ( i R CL,a ion ), electronic resistance overpotential of the anode catalyst layer ( i R CL,a elec ), resistance overpotential of proton exchange membrane (iR membrane), resistance overpotential of the current collector (iR current collector), and overpotential of contact resistance between components (iR contact). For the construction of a cost-performance collaborative design framework, we need to focus on four parameters strongly correlated with the anode catalyst layer: η a, η diff,a, i R CL,a ion , i R CL,a elec . As shown in Fig. 17(c)-I, η a can be correlated with the exchange current density (j 0) through the transformation of Tafel equation. To reduce η a, the j 0 needs to be increased, which in turn requires enhancing the number of active sites per unit area (S active) and the intrinsic activity (k cat) of iridium-based catalysts. The improvement of S active depends on exposing more active sites of catalyst through morphology engineering or defect engineering, and on increasing the catalyst loading within a certain range on the electrode. k cat requires optimizing the types of reaction pathway and the energy barrier of the rate-determining step. Based on this, increasing the number of active sites of catalyst or improving the intrinsic activity can reduce the need to enhance S active by increasing catalyst loading on the electrode, thereby reducing the usage of noble metal iridium. As shown in Fig. 17(c)-II, η diff,a can be reduced by decreasing the thickness of the anode catalyst layer (d) or increasing the volume percentage of pores (φ pores) in the catalyst layer at anode. Decreasing d or increasing φ pores can also balance catalyst cost reduction and η diff,a reduction. It should be noted that the thinning of the catalyst layer at anode must be controlled under the condition that the layer conforms to the idealized cuboid model. The ionic resistance overpotential of the anode catalyst layer ( i R CL,a ion ) is the product of the current (i) and the ionic resistance of the anode catalyst layer ( i R CL,c ion ), meaning that the higher the current, the greater the contribution of R CL,a ion to the electrolyzer performance. The determining formula for R CL,a ion is shown in Fig. 17(c)-Ⅲ. It can be deduced that decreasing d or increasing φ Nafion will reduce and increase the iridium loading in the catalyst layer, respectively, but both lead to a decrease R CL,a ion , indicating that the change of R CL,a ion in caused by variations in iridium loading needs to be analyzed based on specific systems. In addition to Nafion ionomer, some studies suggest that certain special catalysts can also provide non-negligible ionic conductivity [131]. The electronic resistance of the anode catalyst layer ( R CL,a elec ) has a similar expression form to R CL,a ion , with the research object changing from ionic transport to electron transport, as shown in Fig. 17(c)-IV. The change in R CL,a elec caused by iridium loading also requires system-specific analysis. Although the specific trend depends on the system, it is certain that reducing R CL,a elec can decrease the driving voltage. Thus, improving the electron conductivity (κ cat) of the catalyst layer at anode, such as by preparing highly conductive catalysts or enhancing the conductive network of catalysts in the catalyst layer, can improve performance. Based on the above discussion on the correlation between electrode loading of iridium-based catalysts and driving voltage, several parameters related to catalyst properties can be identified: ρ cat, f Ir, k cat, S active, σion and κ cat, as shown in Fig. 17(d). These parameters correspond to catalyst properties: bulk density, iridium content, intrinsic activity, the number of exposed active sites, surface ionic conductivity, and surface electron conductivity. In the design of iridium-based catalyst, these parameters can be regulated, combined with the previously discussed cost-performance correlation analysis, to develop low-cost and high-performance iridium-based catalyst systems more suitable for engineering applications. 5.2 Current advances in design strategies for improving performance Intrinsic activity (related to k cat) of iridium-based catalysts can be optimized based on OER catalytic mechanisms. Firstly, from the viewpoint of optimizing the adsorption energy in the AEM pathway, catalysts with high activity can be designed directionally. Guo et al. [166] designed an Ir/MnO x catalyst where the introduction of Mn weakens the adsorption capability of the Ir site for O atoms (Fig. 18(a) ). This modification leads to a shift in the potential-determining step (PDS) of the OER from the *OOH to O2 step to the *O to *OOH step, resulting in a reduction of the energy barrier of the PDS and subsequently enhancing the intrinsic activity. Secondly, promoting the Lattice Oxygen Mechanism (LOM) can improve the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. Wang et al. [167] incorporated Nd into the iridium oxide lattice, generating Ir-O-Nd structures. This not only created Ir-O-Nd bonds but also disrupted the long-range ordered structure of iridium oxide, generating a large number of oxygen vacancies (Fig. 18(b)). The Ir-O-Nd structure reduces the adsorption energy at iridium sites, enhancing activity via the AEM mechanism. The presence of numerous oxygen vacancies further promotes the OER via the more active LOM pathway. Furthermore, promoting the oxygen evolution pathway (OPM) can also enhance the intrinsic activity of the catalyst. Wang et al. [168] introduced both Ir and Ru into a β-MnO2 matrix (Fig. 18(c)). The close interatomic distance between Ir and Ru within the β-MnO2 matrix facilitates the formation of a bridging O-O structure, thereby promoting the OER through the more active OPM pathway. In addition to intrinsic activity, the number of active sites per unit mass (related to S active) and the conductivity (related to κ cat) of the catalyst are crucial for the expression of activity in oxygen evolution catalysis [105,171]. This is particularly important in PEMWE electrolyzers, where the catalyst’s inherent properties are closely related to the electrolyzer performance. The increase in the number of active sites per unit mass leads to a more uniform charge distribution on the catalyst surface and shorter electron transfer pathways. This results in a reduced activation overpotential, thereby lowering the required cell voltage at a given current density for catalysts with high density of active sites. On the other hand, maintaining high electrical conductivity helps to minimize the ohmic resistance, thus reducing the ohmic overpotential. As a result, catalysts with high conductivity require a lower cell voltage at the same current density. As shown in Fig. 18(d), Zou et al. [169] designed a honeycomb-structured iridium oxide foam catalyst. The porous structure exposes more active sites. This catalyst exhibited a cell performance of 2.0 V at 3.4 A cm–2 in a PEMWE electrolyzer using a Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, outperforming a similar catalyst with fewer exposed active sites, which achieved 2.0 V at 2.8 A cm–2. As shown in Fig. 18(e), Ferner et al. [170] reported a composite catalyst that combines Pt black as a conductive aid with commercial IrO x . This composite catalyst, with a mass ratio of commercial iridium oxide to platinum black ranging from 1:1.05 to 1.21, exhibited superior performance in electrolyzer tests compared to pure commercial IrO x while reducing the use of iridium. Beyond the aforementioned activity design strategies, the doped and supported catalysts we previously introduced typically enable a reduction in the iridium content (f Ir) to decrease the overall bulk density (ρ cat) of the catalyst to some extent. This is because the introduction of heteroatoms into the catalytic system induces dispersion and site-occupation effects. Research on the ionic conductivity (σ ion) of the catalysts is relatively scarce. Apart from the exceptional case cited earlier, the σ ion of most catalysts are far lower than those of ionomers. Future investigations into enhancing the σ ion of catalysts hold promise for reducing the use of non-conductive ionomers, thereby improving the electronic conductivity of the catalyst layer. The catalytic stability represents another critical metric of catalyst performance, reflecting the dynamic evolution of catalyst activity over time. Parameters including, but not limited to, ρ cat, f Ir, k cat, S active, σion and κ cat undergo dynamic changes over time, which directly or indirectly influence catalyst stability. Herein, we introduce strategies for enhancing catalyst stability, ranging from the inherent stability of iridium itself to various stabilizing effects. As shown in Fig. 19(a) , the Pourbaix diagram is a phase equilibrium diagram for specific potentials and pH conditions. In the yellow region of the diagram, where the pH is between 1 and 3 and the oxidation potential is above 1.23 V, iridium tends to exist in the form of insoluble solid iridium oxide [172]. The electrochemical properties of iridium are the foundation for its intrinsic stability. The structural stability of iridium-based catalysts affects their electrochemical stability. Zhang et al. [87] calculated higher oxygen vacancy formation energy in Mn-IrO2 than in IrO2, explaining its enhanced stability (Fig. 19(b)). Additionally, Cherevko et al. [176] proposed an S-number descriptor to evaluate the stability of catalysts. The S-number is defined as the ratio of the number of oxygen molecules produced during oxygen evolution to the number of iridium atoms dissolved. A larger S-number indicates that a large amount of oxygen is produced with minimal iridium dissolution, thus reflecting stronger catalyst stability. Various effects can be utilized to suppress iridium dissolution. Xia et al. [173] designed an H3.8Ir1-x Ru x O4 catalyst, where the compositional effect of Ru, via Ru-O-Ir bonds, transfers charge to Ir, inhibiting its overoxidation and dissolution (Fig. 19(c)). This results in an S-number of 177248 for H3.8Ir1–x Ru x O4, which is twice that of the comparison sample H3.8IrO4 (S-number 82930). The anchoring effect is a common stability strategy, anchoring iridium sites via substrate lattice or support heterointerface chemical bonds. Xing et al. [146] introduced iridium atoms into the lattice of a PdO substrate to design a single-atom catalyst structure (Fig. 19(d)). The substrate lattice limits the dissolution of iridium atoms, ensuring the stability of Ir sites. The catalyst, using 0.06 mgIr cm–2 of iridium in a PEMWE electrolyzer with a Nafion 115 membrane at 80 °C, exhibited a cell performance of 1.89 V at 2 A cm–2, and it remained stable for 400 h at a current density of 1 A cm–2. The hydroxylation effect on the surface of oxygen evolution catalysts also affects their stability. Stephens et al. [174] found that increasing the hydroxyl coverage on the catalyst surface causes the Ir–O bond to elongate, thereby enhancing the oxygen evolution activity via the AEM pathway and suppressing the overoxidation of iridium on the surface (Fig. 19(e)). The self-healing effect is a unique stability mechanism. Compared to other effects, the catalyst surface undergoes dissolution, but the surface structure can dynamically stabilize through re-deposition. Wang et al. [175] studied the self-healing effect on the surface of Ir/MnO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 19(f), in state 1, the dissolution of divalent manganese and trivalent iridium occurs. In state 2, manganese and iridium are redeposited on the catalyst surface as trivalent manganese and iridium in oxidation states greater than four, respectively. In state 3, the surface structure remains intact while water attacks. In state 4, the trivalent manganese undergoes disproportionation, converting to divalent manganese. In state 5, the surface structure remains intact with water attack. In state 6, during the oxygen evolution reaction, high-valent iridium is converted to trivalent iridium, achieving regeneration of the catalyst surface structure. 6 Conclusion and outlook In summary, this review provides a comprehensive overview of the research on iridium-based catalysts. This review aims to equip researchers with the necessary knowledge base and the latest advancements in the field. Future research on iridium-based catalysts could advance in the following directions: (1) For coexisting reaction mechanisms, quantifying their contributions and developing strategies to balance activity and stability are essential. (2) Current in-situ characterization techniques are predominantly restricted to low-current-density three-electrode systems. There is a need for further development of in-situ techniques applicable to the high-current-density conditions of PEMWE electrolyzers. (3) Understanding activation conditions of design strategies and their interactions is crucial for catalyst performance optimization. (4) A systematic study of the interdependencies among various factors influencing performance evaluation in PEMWE electrolyzers is necessary, along with the establishment of standardized testing protocols. With advancements in enhancing the activity and stability of iridium-based catalysts under high-current-density conditions, PEMWE electrolyzers, combined with cost-reduction strategies, are expected to enable large-scale hydrogen production with high purity and rapid response capabilities. Catal., 2018, 1, 508–515. Meiling Xiao received her PhD degree in physical chemistry from the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2017. She worked at the University of Waterloo as a postdoc and joined Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry in 2021 as a full professor. She was selected for the Special Talent Program B of CAS and the Outstanding Youth Foundation of Jilin Province. She has published over 40 papers in J. Am. Chem. Soc., Angew. Chem. Int. Ed., Adv. Mater., etc. with over 5100 citations, H-factor 33. Her research interests include single-atom heterogeneous catalysis, fuel cells, and water electrolyzers. Changpeng Liu received his PhD in Physical Chemistry in 2002 and was appointed as a professor at the Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry in 2012. He has successively presided over, undertaken, participated in, and completed several national and provincial-level scientific research projects. His research interests center on catalyst materials within the fuel cell and water electrolysis for hydrogen production systems, electrocatalysis and mass transfer processes, electrode interfaces, and membrane electrodes, the design and assembly of bipolar plate flow fields and fuel cell stacks, water, heat, and energy efficiency management, as well as the integration and application of system devices. Wei Xing received his PhD in physical chemistry at the Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry (CIAC) in 1995. He worked at the Hong Kong Productivity Council (HKPC), researching the electrochemical treatment of metal surfaces. In 2001, he joined the CIAC as a professor and devoted his work to the development of advanced chemical power sources. He has received several awards, including the Jilin Province Science and Technology Award, the Science and Technology Award from the Chemical Industry and Engineering Society of China. He has published over 300 papers in peer-reviewed journals and has applied for more than 50 patents. His research areas currently involve proton exchange membrane fuel cells and water electrolyzers from fundamental electro-catalytic processes to relevant stack/system assembly and testing.

coredata.dc:description: Proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE) has garnered significant attention as a pivotal technology for converting surplus electricity into hydrogen for long-term storage, as well as for providing high-purity hydrogen for aerospace and high-end manufacturing applications. With the ongoing commercialization of PEMWE, advancing iridium-based oxygen evolution reaction (OER) catalysts remains imperative to reconcile stringent requirements for high activity, extended longevity, and minimized noble metal loading. The review provides a systematic analysis of the integrated design of iridium-based catalysts in PEMWE, starting from the fundamentals of OER, including the operation environment of OER catalysts, catalytic performance evaluation within PEMWE, as well as catalytic and dissolution mechanisms. Subsequently, the catalyst classification and preparation/characterization techniques are summarized with the focus on the dynamic structure-property relationship. Guided by these understandings, an overview of the design strategies for performance enhancement is presented. Specifically, we construct a mathematical framework for cost-performance optimization to offer quantitative guidance for catalyst design. Finally, future perspectives are proposed, aiming to establish a theoretical framework for rational catalyst design.
